column27: There are some doubts on the “holotype” referred in the original (see compilers preface of Traverse_Ames-1979). In this case, the specimen number is the same for Lophosoria falsa and Alsophila arctua. Possibly, this reflects the presence of multiple spores in the same sample.
column28: Compared to Alsophila multiflora, which is a synonym of Cyathea multiflora. Since there is no detail to assign to a living genus, it remains as a member of Cyatheaceae.
column29: The ‘crease folds’ reported by Bolchotinova_1953 may indicate resemblance to Trichipteris (as reviewed by Gastony (1979) — although all species treated belong within Cyathea, a formal assignment to the genus may be premature. I interpret these ‘crease folds’ as depressed leasurae in the spore as seen in several Trichipteris species (mostly NW), thus I tentatively put this spore in Cyathea.

column29: Aligned with Polypodiales based on the incomplete vertical annulus (unlike the complete and oblique annulus of tree ferns) (Li_etal-2019). But the main feature supporting this (annulus) was scored as missing for this species. It appears that the main character supporting the position is cup-shaped indusium, but the absence of other tree fern families in the analyses warrants caution here. Thus, I keep with the original assignment to a Dicksoniaceous grade.

column30:
A very interesting observation on the ‘Hemitelia-type’ spore morphology was made by Selling, 0 . H. (1946, Studies in Hawaiian pollen statistics. Part I . The spores of the Hawaiian pteridophytes. 87 pp., 7 pls. Bishop Museum, Honolulu, Hawaii), who observed the same  morphology in Hawaiian Cibotium (plate 4, fig. 70) —although he referred to it as abnormal. 
Given that no Cyathea inhabits Hawaii, contamination is quite improbable.
